newsitem.title: FRANCE: Air Littoral plans to issue convertible bond.
newsitem.headline: Air Littoral plans to issue convertible bond.

text.p: French regional airline Air Littoral plans to issue an eight-year convertible bond which would allow German airline Lufthansa to acquire a maximum 15 percent of its capital, Air Littoral chairman Marc Dufour said on Thursday.
Dufour told a news conference that the convertible bond was the financial part of a cooperation agreement signed on Thursday between the two airlines.
He said that the talks had not been finalised.
Frederic Reid, president and chief operating officer of Lufthansa Passenger Airline, said the financial negotiations were subject to supervisory board approval.
He said the airline had told Frankfurt market authorities of its intention to pursue negotiations.
"We have a clear intention," he said.
Under the proposed terms, Lufthansa would be able convert the bonds into Air Littoral shares during an eight-year period into up to 15 percent of the French airline's capital.
No details were given on pricing which is still under negotiation.
In Frankfurt, Lufthansa said the co-operation deal with Air Littoral would entail a code-sharing agreement to 26 destinations in France, Italy and Spain.
Close operation was also envisioned in marketing, sales, customer service, grund service, airline service and cargo services, Lufthansa said.
